About me

I'm a principal scientist at Institute of Marine Research, Norway, and currently working as a visiting scientist at NOAA Northeast Fisheries Science Center in Woods Hole MA, USA.

My background is as a marine mammal biologist (PhD in 2002), but I have since 2002 been developing ecosystem-based science and management (EBM) through leading the Barents Sea ecosystem surveys ('05-'07) and contributing to the Norwegian Integrated Management plans for the Lofoten - Barents Sea ('06), the Norwegian Sea ('09) and the Skagerrak - North Sea ('13).

Developing ecosystem-based marine spatial planning (MSP) has been a cornerstone of my research since 2002 and has broadened my field of view. Successful ecosystem-based management requires comprehensive and relevant science and quantitative tools (eg. Ecosystem model - Atlantis ), as well as comprehensive and relevant governance. Understanding the interactions between the socio-cultural-economic system on one hand and the ecological science needed to support sound management is at the core of my current research.

Research areas:

Ecosystem models

  • Skill assessment of the Northeast US Atlantis model
  • Spatial scenarios (eg. MSP - wind farms) using the Atlantis model
  • Simulating pollution events in ecosystem models
  • Developing R4Atlantis R-statistics package for interacting with Atlantis input and output

    Governance and advice

  • The science base of EBM and MSP
  • Role of experts and models in EBM
  • Importance of culture in marine governance

    • Oil spill assessments and risk

  • Effects of spatial variability in survival on oil spill risk assessments
  • Communication of risks of oil spills
